program.name: Aid to the Aged, Blind, or Disabled (AABD)
program.description:
AABD gives cash each month to people in Illinois who are 65 or older, blind, or disabled. You must have low income and few assets to qualify. The cash can help pay for food, housing, clothes, and other needs.

You can apply online, in person, by phone, or by mail. Select "Apply Now" to see all options. It may take up to 45 days to get this benefit (or 90 days if you must prove you have a disability). 

The estimated value assumes you have less than $2,000 in assets if single, or $3,000 if a couple. Add $50 more for each extra person in your home. Cars worth over $4,500 may count toward this limit. If you cannot get out of bed or a chair for 3 or more months, you may get a higher amount. If you live in a nursing home or care facility, you will get much less (about $60/month).
program.website_description: Cash assistance for aged, blind, or disabled individuals

warning_message.message: If you also applied for SSI (a federal program), you can get AABD money while you wait. But if SSI approves you later, the state will take back the AABD money you received. They do this by keeping part of your first SSI payment.

documents.text: Proof of home address (ex: driver's license, utility bill, or mail with your name and address)
Proof of identity - name and date of birth verification
Proof of status in U.S. (ex: birth certificate, green card, work permit)
Proof of income (ex: pay stubs, tax returns, Social Security statements)

navigators.name: IDHS Family Community Resource Center
navigators.description: Visit your local Family Community Resource Center to apply in person or get help with your AABD application
